text:
Broadway & Canal
v.3 plate 113
Stokes 1836

Stokes, I.N.P.
Iconography of Mqnhattan Island. v.3, pl.113

Broadway, north from Canal Street, showing the coaches that preceded the Broadway surface cars. Intersection shown on the right is Howard Street.

About 1880.

August S. Loeffler.
P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, north side, east from between Broadway and Lafayette Streets.
About 1904.

Brown Brothers.

283 Canal Street, adjoining the N.E. corner of Broadway.
1923.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, south side, west from and including Broadway. This view shows the convergence of Lispenard and Canal Streets, at Broadway.

About 1928.

Canal Street, south side, west from and including Broadway. This view also shows the convergence of Lispenard and Canal Streets, at Broadway.
February 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, north side, west from and including Broadway. Canal Street was laid out along a canal dug to empty the Fresh Water Pond, or Collect (which lay to the northwest of City Hall, roughly between the future Lafayette and Baxter, Pearl and White Streets) into the North River. Originally it began at the future Centre Street, but around 1860 was extended eastward, along the line of, and absorbing, the eastern part of Walker Street.
February 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, north side, east of, adjoining and at the N.E. corner of Broadway.
February 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, south from and including Canal Street, showing in the distance a vague outline of the Woolworth Building. The modern structure on the right is the National City Bank, No. 415 Broadway, occupying the apex caused by the convergence of Canal and Lispenard Streets.

February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, south side, west from Broadway.
June 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, north side, east from West Broadway to Mercer Street. The elevated line shown on West Broadway is the Sixth Ave. system.

June 11, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

(1)

Canal Street, north side, east from (No. 273) but not including Broadway and across Lafayette (Elm, at this date) Street. The 2½-story white structure, on the left is No. 271, at the head of Cortlandt Alley; midway between Broadway and Elm Street. The 6-story lofts, slightly east of same, are Nos. 267-265-261, constructed as a unit with a triangular cornice decoration. Nos 259, 257, 255 and 251 progress in the same direction; the latter being the 5-story structure at the corner (N.W.) of Elm Street. This view is a portion of a stereoscopic scene by John S. Willard of No. 269, the 4-story building bearing a "looking glass" sign.

About 1876.

(2)

A similar scene, from a different angle, at a later date. Note the 2-story structure that replaced Nos. 259 and 257 in View No. 1. This view is slightly east of the vantage point of the preceding scene and shows a portion of the 6-story loft building bearing No. 267-261.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Canal Street, north side, east from (No. 273) but not including Broadway and across Lafayette (Elm, at this date) Street. The 2½-story white structure, on the left is No. 271, at the head of Cortlandt Alley; midway between Broadway and Elm Street. The 6-story lofts, slightly east of same, are Nos. 267-265-261, constructed as a unit with a triangular cornice decoration. Nos 259, 257, 255 and 251 progress in the same direction; the latter being the 5-story structure at the corner (N.W.) of Elm Street. This view is a portion of a stereoscopic scene by John S. Willard of No. 269, the 4-story building bearing a "looking glass" sign.

About 1876.

(2)

A similar scene, from a different angle, at a later date. Note the 2-story structure that replaced Nos. 259 and 257 in View No. 1. This view is slightly east of the vantage point of the preceding scene and shows a portion of the 6-story loft building bearing No. 267-261.

August 3, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

415
179 Broadway showing Palmers Clothing store on right and Canal insurance Company at left.
